I just glanced over the paper Ken linked to (hadn't
read that one...looks interesting).  If I'm reading it
right, you're proposing a "dominance tournament" as
opposed to a "master tournament" (in which champions
of later generations play against champions of past
generations, in order to demonstrate improvement).  If
I'm reading it right, the "dominance tournament" is
more of a "king of the hill" approach, more like a
single-elimination version of the master tournament,
requiring fewer evaluations.  Am I reading it right?

It's an interesting idea.  In TTT, Gomoku, and Go, I'd
planned to test the champions of every 50th generation
or so against an external opponent, like Angeline and
Pollack did in this '93 paper:

http://citeseer.nj.nec.com/cache/papers/cs/1362/http:zSzzSzwww.cis.ohio-state.eduzSzlairzSzTechReportszSzijcai93.pdf/angeline93learning.pdf

For TTT they created a random player, a best player
(that plays a perfect game), and a near player (a best
player that occasionally makes random moves).

They tested their resulting populations against these
three external players, to get a grid like this:

                 RAND    NEAR    BEST    POP
Wins vs. RAND    1125     802     310    781
Draws vs. RAND      0     104     535    471
Wins vs. NEAR       0     144       0     61
Draws vs. NEAR      0     123     360    588
Draws vs. BEST      0       0       0    481

POP was their evolving population.  Such a grid gives
them a decent measure of the progress of their
algorithm.  In the above example, this population won
about as many games against a purely random opponent
as the NEAR player did, which means they are somewhere
between random players and perfect players.

With Checkers, Fogel used human players as his test
field, putting his evolved champion on an on-line
gaming ladder and charting its progress against human
players.

It seems to me that when charting the progress of a
coevolving population, it is probably best to try to
measure their progress against a standard outside of
their own evolutionary environment, and that testing
them against a broad range of strategies is most
desirable.  

In more complex domains, good external opponents are
more difficult to find, especially automated ones.

I'm pretty sure using Angeline and Pollacks approach
to TTT and Gomoku will provide a good measure of
progress, but I'm not quite sure how we'll handle
measuring improvement with Go.  Many researchers test
against GnuGo or other publicly available Go AIs, and
that seems like a reasonable approach.  It might be a
good idea to measure improvement in a blended way,
with a dominance tournament and testing against
external opponents.

Derek
